questions.text: Which of the following in not included in primary survey in TRIAGE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Primary survey includes- Airway, Breathing, Circulation

A: Airway: 
1: Chin life and Jaw thrust 
•	(No head/ neck tilt)
2: Oropharyngeal tube: Guedel’s oropharyngeal airway
3: Endotracheal or Nasopharyngeal intubation
•	Fibreoptic bronchoscopy and intubation is best.
•	Inline intubation
•	Drug assisted intubation > Rapid sequence intubation.
4: Cricothyroidotomy
5: Tracheostomy

B: Breathing

C: Circulation

questions.text: False statement about abdominal trauma is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

(First investigation is CEC is stable and FAST in unstable patient)

Evaluation of haemodynamically stable blunt abdominal trauma

• FAST has the highest likelihood ratio for the presence of intra-abdominal injury. 

• A CT scan of the abdomen is highly sensitive for the diagnosis of solid organ injury, vascular injury, and pelvic fractures, and is the radiographic study of choice to rule out intra-abdominal injury. It is less effective in the diagnosis of diaphragmatic or bowel injuries. 

•	The presence of free intraperitoneal fluid on an abdominal CT scan, without evidence of a solid organ injury, raises concern of a hollow organ injury. In this group of patients, diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) may be useful.

•	DPL involves making a small midline incision below the umbilicus and using a needle and small catheter to aspirate intraperitoneal fluid to assess for blood or bile. 

•	If the aspirate (DPA) is found to contain 10 mL of gross blood or bile, an exploratory laparotomy is indicated

questions.text: While trying to insert a central venous catheter into a subclavian vein, a patient developed sudden onset dyspnoea and absent breath sounds on the right side. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CVP complications, includes: 

•	Mechanical complications: Arterial puncture, hematoma, and pneumothorax. 

•	Infections:

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in the 5th ICS
Immediate Intercostal drain in the 5th ICS

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient was brought to the ER after RTA, his RR is 25/min, BP is 80/45 mmHg. On examination, hyper-resonance is heard over the left side of the chest. The chest X-ray performed is given below. What could be the appropriate management in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tension pneumothorax is initially managed by needle insertion at 5th intercostal space and when the patient becomes stable then ICD can be done.

Closed pneumothorax is best managed by ICD while open pneumothorax is managed by ICD and closure of the wound.

questions.text: Young adult, RTA- multiple rib fracture / Flail chest. Which type of breathing will be found?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Flail chest 

When 3 or more consecutive ribs are fractured in 2 or more places, a free-floating, unstable segment of chest wall is produced. This is called flail chest. Physical examination reveals paradoxical motion of the flail segment. The chest wall moves inward with inspiration and outward with expiration. Endotracheal intubation and positive pressure mechanical ventilation is treatment of choice. Various operations have been devised for correcting flail chest. These include the application of external fixation devices or the placement of plates or pins for internal fixation. 

Chest x-ray will show 
•	Multiple rib fractures 
•	Underlying lung contusion 
•	Hemopneumothorax 	
Indications of intubation are: 
•	Significant other injuries (ISS >50) 
•	Respiratory rate more than 35 per min 
•	Partial pressure oxygen less than 8.0 kPa 
•	Partial pressure carbon dioxide greater than 6.6 kPa 
•	Vital capacity less than 12 ml / kg 
•	Right to left shunt of more than 15%

questions.text: A trauma patient was brought to emergency who has cold clammy skin, increased JVP prominent neck veins and heart sound were not audible. Patient died in the hospital. Autopsy finding is given in the image. What is most probable cause of death.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This is traumatic Cardiac tamponade as the blood can be seen in pericardial space. is a medical emergency as the collection in  the pericardial sac compressing the heart and leading to a decrease in cardiac output and shock (Obstructive shock which later progresses to cardiogenic shock).
It is characterized by Beck’s triad-
1.	Hypotension: Low blood pressure 
2.	Muffled heart sounds: 
3.	Raised JVP

questions.text: A young man sustained a lathi blow over lateral part of head. He was brought to emergency. On arrival, GCS is 9/15 and urgent NCCT was performed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Young age group as the dura can more easily be striped away from bone. 
•	A fracture overlies the haematoma in nearly all (95%) adults and most (75%) children. 
•	Bleeding arterial – Middle meningeal artery (rarely sinus veins)
•	Features of increased ICP may develop: 
1.	Headache / Deteriorating conscious state/ Focal neurological signs (dilated pupil, hemiparesis)/ Change in vital signs. 
•	Prognosis is excellent if haematoma is drained early. 
•	Lucid interval found
•	CT scan- Biconvex

Concavo-convex image is SDH. Some SDH are managed conservatively.

•	Older age

CT- concavo-convex (acute – white; Chronic-  black)

questions.text: Base of the skull fracture presents with involvement of the petrous temporal bone, which of the following sign will be found in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Battle sign

Base of Skull Fractures

Anterior fossa fracture- May open into the frontal or ethmoid air sinuses or run across the cribriform plate.

•           Presents with sub conjunctival hematoma,anosmia, epistaxis, nasal tip anaesthesia, CSF- rhinorrhea and occasionally carotico-cavernous fistua.

•           Periobital haematoma or “raccoon eye” indicate subgaleal haemorrhage.

Middle fossa fracture involving petrous temporal bone presents with CSF otorrhea, haemotympanum, occicular disruption, Battle sign or VII and VIII cranial nerve palsies.

•           Battle sign – bruising behind the ear appearing 36 hours after a head injury with a petrous temporal base of skull fracture.

questions.text: Not included in Damage control surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be injured in seat belt injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Splenic rupture

questions.text: A 24 year old male was brought to emergency with RTA. He is conscious and oriented. He is complaining of breathlessness and pain in left upper abdomen. There is decreased breath sound in left side of chest. X ray image is given below. Which of the following procedure is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This is a case of traumatic diaphragmatic hernia where ICD insertion in contraindicated
The finding of an airfluid level in the left lower chest with a nasogastric tube entering it after blunt trauma to the abdomen is diagnostic of diaphragmatic rupture with gastric herniation into the chest. This lesion needs to be fixed immediately. With continuing negative pressure in the chest, each breath sucks more of the abdominal contents into the chest and increases the likelihood of vascular compromise of the herniated viscera. While the diaphragm is easily fixed from the left chest, this injury should be approached from the abdomen. The possibility of injury below the diaphragm after sufficient blunt injury to rupture the diaphragm mandates examination of the intraabdominal solid and hollow viscera; adequate exposure of the diaphragm to allow secure repair is possible from this approach.

questions.text: A 40 yr old 100 kg man is involved in a house fire with 45% burn (of total TBSA). He comes to the emergency 2 hrs since his injury. He has not received any resuscitation, after inserting 2 IV lines, according to parkland formula, the rate of initial I.V. fluid should be.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1500 ml/ hr.

•	According to Parkland formula, IV fluid is calculated by the formula 4ml/ kg/ % of TBSA for the first 24 Hrs. with half given in first 8 hrs and rest given in next 6 hrs. 

•	This formula predicts that this man will require 18000 ml of Isotonic fluid in first 24 hrs (4 × 100 × 45). 

•	One half should be given in first 8 hrs after injury. 

•	After a lapse of 2 hrs, 9000 ml fluid is required for next 6 hrs. 

•	Thus the initial rate should be 1500 ml/ Hr.

choices.text: Type I collagen replacing type III
Type III collagen replacing type I
Type II collagen replacing type IV
Type IV collagen replacing type II

questions.text: Remodelling phase of wound healing is characterised by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Early scar (initial phase of final scar)- 

•	Type III: Type I ratio is 1:1:- 

•	Raised hard pink itchy

Final scar – 

•	Collagen Type I: III= 4:1

•	Soft pale flat supple

Increase in fibroblast concentration is a feature of proliferative phase not in remodelling phase

Remodelling Phase (Maturation)

•	6 weeks to 6 months - 1 or 2 year

•	Maturation of collagen, - Crosslinking and realignment of collagen fibre along the line of tension. 

•	Reduces wound vascularity

•	Fibroblast and myofibroblast cause wound contraction

•	Type I collagen replaces Type III

•	Early extracellular matrix- Fibronectic and collagen type III > glycosaminoglycans and proteoglycans. Final matrix contain type I collagen

•	Collagen deposition in wound is assessed by hydroxyproline excreted in urine (in proliferative phase)

•	Collagen is Broken down by collagenase and MMP

Procollagen > Collagen fibril > Cross linking > Collagen fibre > Deposition > Degradadation and collagenolysis through collagenase.

questions.text: Trophic ulcer are caused by all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Trophic ulcers (neuropathic ulcers) are penetrating ulcers, caused by loss of sensation or pressure.
Main causes are- DM, Leprosy, Tabes dorsalis, Syringomyelia, infection

Usually found at heel or sole, generally painless. Arterial pulsations are normal while neurological sensations are deficient.

questions.text: A patient who has a burn scar for last 15 years comes with a fresh ulcer over the scar. In spite of regular dressing the ulcer is gradually progressing. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Marjolin’s ulcer

Marjolin ulcer

A Marjolin ulcer is a cutaneous malignancy that arises in the setting of previously injured skin, longstanding scars, and burns.

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most frequent malignancy identified on histopathologic 
Examination. Visually, the lesions have been described as ulcerative and foul-smelling with rapid growth and rolled elevated margins.

Management should focus on prevention as unresected burn wounds that heal by secondary intention are at increased risk for malignant degeneration Management should focus on prevention as unresected burn wounds that heal by secondary intention are at increased risk for malignant degeneration

This patient’s history of burns and the image is suggestive of a Marjolin’s ulcer. It is a rare and aggressive form of squamous cell carcinoma that grows from burns, scars, or poorly healing wounds. It presents as an indurated, non- tender ulcer with raised and everted edges with scarring in the surrounding area with marked fibrosis

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition based on the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Carbuncle: A carbuncle is an infection of the hair follicle(s) that extends into the surrounding skin and deep underlying subcutaneous tissue. Carbuncles are clusters of furuncles connected subcutaneously, causing deeper suppuration and scarring.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic patient presents with extreme pain in the right side of his trunk. On examination, blisters and a woody surface are noted. The image of his trunk is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Necrotizing fasciitis

The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of necrotizing fasciitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A B-hemolytic Streptococcus). Necrotizing fasciitis is a rapidly progressive necrosis of the subcutaneous tissues and fascia. The source of the infection is either the skin following trauma or a surgical incision. Diabetes mellitus is the most common comorbidity associated with the condition.

questions.text: Which one of the following is NOT a feature of re-feeding syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Refeeding syndrome

• Hypophosphatemia is considered a hallmark of refeeding syndrome (RS) and it can cause arrhythmias.

• Other electrolyte irregularities is decreased  magnesium, potassium, and thiamine.

• Hypoalbuminemia, hyponatremia, and hypocalcemia are not associated with RS.

With rising glucose levels, the body produces a countermeasure of insulin levels, which drives phosphorus and potassium intracellularly, causing a decrease in the amount of available extracellular potassium or hypokalemia.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male smoker with a known case of Buerger's disease undergoes lumbar sympathectomy where both L1 ganglions are removed. What is the side effect which he can suffer from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

L1 sympathetic is the supply for bladder neck (internal sphincter). If L1 is cut then bladder neck is unable to close during ejaculation leading to retrograde ejaculation.

questions.text: The patient presented to OPD with dilated tortuous leg vein, with a history of trauma 10 years back on the same region, On examination pulsatile vein is also visible, what is likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 50 year old smoker male presents with pain along the right arm and ptosis. His chest radiograph shows a soft tissue opacity at the right lung apex with destruction of adjacent ribs. The picture is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Superior pulmonary sulcus tumors, also called Pancoast tumors, arise from the apical pleuropulmonary groove located superior to the first rib. When these tumors involve the surrounding structures such as the brachial plexus, cervical paravertebral sympathetic nervous system, and stellate ganglion, they cause a group of signs and symptoms that are collectively called Pancoast syndrome. This is characterized by ipsilateral shoulder and arm pain, paresthesias, paresis and atrophy of the thenar muscles of the hand, and Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis). 
Pancoast syndrome refers to the collective group of symptoms associated with these tumors, which is secondary to the involvement of brachial plexus and associated chest wall, vertebral, or rib pain. Shoulder or arm pain with associated paresthesias along the medial half of the fourth, fifth fingers and medial side of the hand, arm, and forearm due to C8 through T1 radiculopathy are usually primary symptoms associated. Since they are apically located, pulmonary symptoms of shortness of breath do not develop until later, as the tumor begins to involve more of the lung.

questions.text: A 50-years-old male presented in the emergency with high BP (160/100) and heart rate of 120/min. A CECT is done which is given below. What is the management of this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aortic dissection
•    Patient presents with severe tearing chest pain in retrostrenum

questions.text: A 3-year child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of the lateral neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found In the lateral side of the neck as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cystic hygroma-
•	Due to sequestration of Jugular lymph sac
•	Lined by endothelial lining/ content clear lymph
•	Multiloculated
•	Turner syndrome/ Down syndrome: Higher incidence
•	M/C site - Posterior triangle/ (rarely at- Axilla/ Mediastinum/ retro-peritoneum/ Groin)
•	50% present at birth/ May regress spontaneously
•	Partially compressible/ Brilliantly transilluminant
•	May cause obstructed labour or post partum respiratory distress
Treatment
•	Surgical excision
•	Sclerosing agent: Bleomycin/ OK432 (picibanil- derived lyophilized streptococcus pyogenes)
•	EXIT procedure: Ex utero intrapartum treatment

questions.text: A patient presented with a swelling on the anterior border of sternomastoid muscle in the lower part of the neck. This swelling represent the remnant of which of the following branchial clefts?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Branchial cyst
•	Remanent of 2nd branchial cleft
•	Older children and adolescent
•	 Cystic swelling at anterior border of sternocleidomastoid (upper and middle 1/3rd)
•	Lined by squamous epithelium (in 90%) or rarely ciliated columnar epithelium.
•	Dx: USG and FNAC (CECT)
•	Thick turbid fluid with cholesterol crystals
•	Treatment: Excision

questions.text: The most common site of the internal opening of a branchial fistula is at the?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tonsillar fossa
Brachial fistula 
External opening: Situation in the lower third of the neck, near the anterior border of sternomastiod. 
Internal opening: Anterior aspect of posterior faucial pillar 
•	Branchial fistula opens at lower 1/3rd of ant border of sternomastoid. Internal opening is at ant aspect of Posterior tonsillar pillar.
•	Lined by Ciliated columnar
•	Runs between structures developing from 2nd and 3rd brachial arches (Between ECA, 7th CN and ICA and 9th CN). Behind posterior belly of digastric and stylohyoid and above IJV, stylopharyngeus, 9th and 12th CN and perforates superior constrictor.

•	Branchial cyst develops from failure of obliteration of the second branchial cleft
•	Present at junction of upper and middle 1/3rd of ant border of sternomastoid
•	Usually presents in 2nd or 3rd decade 
•	Lined by squamous epithelium
•	FNAC cholesterol crystals

questions.text: What should be the treatment for the condition in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

An angular dermoid occurs at the outer angle of the eye. Tumours of embryonic origin that arise along bony sutures as a result of abnormal ectodermal sequestration during development. It contains elements derived from two germ layers: mesoderm and ectoderm. Developmentally, these tumors are thought to represent inclusions of ectoderm along the lines of closing fissures

Early surgical excision is recommended

questions.text: A young boy presented with a bluish-red cystic swelling on the left side of the floor of the mouth as shown below. On examination, it showed fluctuation and transillumination. It was initially 1.5 cm, and progressed to 5 cm in the last few months. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ranula: A extravasation cyst of sublingual gland.

The given scenario and the image of a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth are suggestive of a ranula. Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as ‘frog’s belly”, as it resembles the vocal sacs of a frog.

Accessory nerve, sternocleidomastoid, and internal jugular veins

questions.text: Structure(s) preserved in case of MRND 1 are?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Only spinal accessory nerve
Structure preserved in MRND 1 is only the spinal accessory nerve.
There are three types of modified radical neck dissection (MRND). Structures preserved are:
- MRND 1-Only spinal accessory nerve
- MRND 2-Accessory nerve and internal jugular vein
- MRND 3 i. e., functional neck dissection Accessory nerve, sternocleidomastoid, and intemal jugular veins.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It is caused by cross communication between parasympathetic auriculo-temporal nerve and sympathetic “superior” cervical ganglion not middle cervical ganglion.

questions.text: During excision of ranula along with sublingual gland which structure is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lingual nerve is in close proximity of Submandibular gland duct

questions.text: A patient came to OPD with chief complaint of swelling in the thyroid region which moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue, there is rupture of swelling with pus discharge, what is the preferred treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	A thyroglossal duct cyst is the most common of the clinically important anomalies of thyroid development.
•	It develops due to persistence of thyroglossal duct. 
•	Most common position is sub-hyoid.
•	It moves up with swallowing and protrusion of tongue
•	In some cases, it may contain whole thyroid gland which can cause hypothyroidism after surgical removal. Therefore, thyroid scan is always done before surgery to locate the position of thyroid 
•	In 1% it may develop papillary thyroid cancer.
•	Sistrunk operation - Removal of the cyst or sinus along with central part of the hyoid bone and dissection of the tract to the base of the tongue.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents to the OPD with diffuse goitre and raised T3and T4. Thyroid Scan showed whole thyroid was hot. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Features of Graves disease-
•    Most common cause of Hyperthyroidism- Autoimmune caused by TSH- R antibody (Graves disease)
•    More common in females (Young middle age)
•    Associated with HLA B8, HLA DR3, HLA DQA1*0501, CTLA-4
•    Younger patient gets CNS complication (More common), older patient get CVS symptoms. Most common GI symptom is increased bowel movement
•    T4, T3 is high and TSH low, 
•    Treatment – 
•    First make the patient euthyroid by hypothyroid drugs. Symptoms improve in 2 weeks and patient become euthyroid in 6 weeks.
•    In recurrent hyperthyroid, non-responders, or drug allergy necessitates permanent treatment by Radio-I or surgery
•    Radio- I is treatment of choice. 
•    Old patient are treated by Radio-I and young by Surgery

questions.text: A patient with a thyroid lesion undergoes a thyroidectomy. The pathologist receives the specimen and the image of the slide is shown below. These cells are seen in which of the following cancers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) represents 75 % of thyroid carcinomas. 
o	PTC is often multifocal and frequently metastasizes to cervical lymph nodes. 
o	A young age at diagnosis is a favorable prognostic factor, and even involvement of cervical nodes does not affect the prognosis adversely.
o	Total thyroidectomy is appropriate for patients with gross evidence of bilateral disease, multifocal PTC, or a history of neck irradiation or for unilateral tumors larger than 1 to 1.5 cm. 
o	Advantages of total thyroidectomy include the ability to treat extrathyroidal metastases or recurrences with RAI and to use serum thyroglobulin to monitor therapy. 
o	Complications of total thyroidectomy include hypoparathyroidism and recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury (1%). 
o	Prophylactic node dissection has no role in papillary cancer but patients with clinically evident lymph node involvement should undergo ipsilateral central or lateral neck dissection at the time of thyroidectomy (Functional neck dissection).
o	Radioablation of metastatic or residual cancer and residual thyroid tissue is performed with 75 to 100 mCi (Mili Curie) of 131I at 4 weeks after total thyroidectomy while the patient is hypothyroid (i.e., TSH 30 µIU/mL on no replacement of T4). 
o	Lifelong long-term suppression of TSH therapy with thyroid hormone replacement decreases recurrences and may improve survival.

questions.text: A 31-year-old female presents with a goitre. On investigation has high TSH and high anti-TPO value. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anti TPO with hypothyroidism is suggestive of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

questions.text: In Medullary Carcinoma thyroid Tumour marker is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Calcitonin

MEDULLARY THYROID CARCINOMA: 5%

  • It can be associated with other endocrine tumors – MEN II A and B
  • F> M. (except for inherited cancers). Commonest in 5th – 6th decades. >50% are bilateral.
  • Regional metastases (spread to neck lymph nodes) occurs early in the disease
  • Spread to distant organs (metastasis) occurs late and can be to the liver, bone, brain, and adrenal medulla
  • Diarrhoea is common
  • FNAC shows amyloid stroma.
  • Usually originates in the upper central lobe of the thyroid
  • Poor prognostic factors include age >50, male, distant spread (metastases), and when seen in patients with other endocrine tumors due to MEN II-B syndrome.
  • Residual disease (following surgery) or recurrence can be detected by calcitonin.
  • Germ line abnormality of chromosome 10 (pericentrometric region) is related to 3 different familial pattern (MEN II a, MEN II b, and non MEN medullayr carcinoma).
  • MTC is screened by Pantagastin stimulated or calcium stimulated plasma level of calcitonin.
  • Though calcitonin is high but hypercalcemia is not a notable feature. 
  • Treatment: Total thyroidectomy with central node dissection. If neck nodes are positive or big tumour than Radical neck dissection should be done.
  • “Prophylactic Total thyroidectomy is indicated in RET positive (MEN syndrome) in childhood. In MEN 2a it is done < 5 years while in MEN 2b it is done < 1 years”. If calcitonin is high than central neck dissection can be added with total thyroidectomy.
  • In setting of Familial MCT patient with basal or stimulated calcitonin relative should undergo a total thyroidectomy and central neck dissection
  • It is important to screen for catecholamine excess prior to surgical exploration to rule out familial syndrome with an occult pheochromocytoma.
  • Radio-I has no role in treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Parathyroid hyperplasia

choices.text: Serum calcium >1 mg/dL above the upper limits of normal

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for parathyroidectomy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Creatinine clearance < 90 ml

Creatinine clearance <60 mL/min is an indication of parathyroidectomy in primary hyperparathyroidism. Asymptomatic Primary Hyperparathyroidism – Incidental findings of hypercalcemia during biochemical screening tests account for 80% of cases. In asymptomatic hyperparathyroidism, the mean serum calcium concentration is less than 1.0 mg/dL above the upper limit of the normal range. At the National Institutes of Health consensus conference, “asymptomatic” PHPT was defined as “the absence of common symptoms and signs of PHPT, including no bone, renal, gastrointestinal, or neuromuscular disorders.”

questions.text: A patient with a history of abdominal and psychic moans, fatigue and she was diagnosed of having a brown tumor, she visited the OPD with following presentation and X-ray, which investigation you do next?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Abdominal pain, Psychic moans and Brown tumour is suggestive of hyperparathyroidism.
•	Tc 99 sestamibi scanning for persistent hyperparathyroidism has a sensitivity of greater than 90% in the case of solitary adenomas. 
•	When combined with single-photon emission computed tomography scanning, it can be used effectively to localize ectopic and usual parathyroid adenomas and, therefore, is the imaging study of choice (SPECT).

questions.text: A postpartum lactating female presents with redness and pain of her breast, as seen in the given image. What is the most likely causative factor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cracked nipple is the most common cause of breast abscess in lactating females.
Breast abscess is best diagnosed on USG and treated by I and D.

Overexpression of HER-2-neu

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm as shown in the image below. Which cancer is more likely to develop in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stewert Travis syndrome is development of Angiosarcoma over chronic lymphedema after MRM/ RT following breast cancer treatment

choices.text: Palatine, frontonasal and secondary nasal processes.
Palatine, frontonasal, secondary nasal processes and mandibular processes.

questions.text: Complete bilateral cleft palate is due to failure of fusion of the?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Palatine processes.

Cleft lip:

  • Central (Rare)- failure of fusion of 2 median median nasal process (Philtrum defect)
  • Lateral (common)- Failure of fusion between median frontonasal process with maxillary process (MCQ). L > R

Cleft palate:

Primary: Non fusion of median nasal process with median palatine shelves (Maxillary process).

• Secondary: Non fusion of Palatine shelves with each other.

12 -18 months

questions.text: A patient sustains an RTA and is taken to the emergency room where he is found to have a pelvic fracture and there is blood at the tip of the meatus of the penis. What is the next step in management?

Suprapubic catheterization

questions.text: A New born baby was having difficulty in breathing and on evaluation there were multiple air fluid levels noted in the left hemithorax. X ray picture given below. What will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bochdalek hernia is left posterior hernia (M/C- > 90%), presents with respiratory distress after birth. Abdomen is scaphoid and heart is pushed to right side. Pressure ventilation is C/I (No Ambu bag mask ventilation). Ventilation is done by ECMO (Extra-corporeal membrane ventilation). Early repair does not improve survival. Most common cause of mortality is pulmonary arterial HT and pulmonary hypoplasia. Morgagni Hernia is rare- Presents late in adults. Colon is most common herniated organ.

questions.text: A young woman presents as shown below, which is triggered by cold temperatures and emotional stress. Episodes usually affect the fingers and toes along with the numbness and pain in the affected areas. There is no underlying illness or co-morbidity in the patient. Comment on the diagnosis:-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Primary Raynaud phenomena

Raynaud phenomenon characterized is by three changes in color.

1. White -both capillary and venous spasms seen. 

2. Blue- capillary are still in spasm but veins opened. 

3. Crimson red- arteries and venues opened up.

Raynaud’s disease This idiopathic condition usually occurs in young women and affects the hands more than the feet.  There is abnormal sensitivity in the arteriolar response to cold. These vessels constrict and the digits (usually the fingers) turn white and become incapable of fine movements. The capillaries then dilate and fill with slowly flowing deoxygenated blood, resulting in the digits becoming swollen and dusky. As the attack passes off, the arterioles relax, oxygenated blood returns into the dilated capillaries and the digits become red.  Thus, the condition is recognized by the characteristic sequence of blanching, dusky cyanosis, and red engorgement, often accompanied by pain. Superficial necrosis is very uncommon. This condition must be distinguished from Raynaud,s syndrome, which has similar features. Treatment of Raynaud’s disease consists of protection from cold and avoidance of pulp and nail bed infection. Calcium antagonists, such as nifedipine, may also have a role to play and electrically heated gloves can be useful in winter. Sympathectomy has been used in the past but it is either ineffective or its effects are short-lived.
